Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Unraveling the Deep History of Avian Neurological Complexity: Implications for the Origins of Flight and Organization of the Modern Avian Brain
Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite advances in knowledge of brain function, the relationship between brain evolution and ecological diversity remains poorly known. A prominent example is that of birds. Taking to the air enabled the dinosaurian ancestors of birds to exploit a range of ecological niches that now underlie the remarkable modern diversity of the group (approximately 10,000 living species). A significant part of this evolutionary success may have stemmed from the development of a relatively large brain, which has been considered necessary for coordinating the various, nuanced components of powered flight. This study complements the NSF BRAIN initiative by using a cross-disciplinary approach to understand the complex neurological evolution of birds and their dinosaurian relatives. To that end, an array of new techniques and new applications of existing technologies are employed to document the major changes in the brain associated with the origin of powered flight. This study also will establish a model of brain expansion complementing that already available for mammals. The outcome will be an unprecedented database of avian brain anatomy that includes not only imagery of morphological systems but also their relation to data generated through brain function.

The relationship between neuroanatomical, cognitive and behavioral evolution remains poorly understood, especially in deep time and across the vertebrate tree of life. This study addresses this relationship using a cross-disciplinary investigation of the evolutionary link between the large brain of living birds and the morphological changes that mark the transition from cursorial (running) dinosaur to flying bird. Initial steps use innovative imaging methods and novel staining techniques to generate the first data on what areas of the brain birds use while flying, and how this activity differs from that of other behaviors. These data will serve as a framework for a broad analysis of encephalization (increasing head size) within living birds and along the lineage where avian flight originated. Shared landmarks will be used to subdivide the endocranial cavity into functionally relevant partitions that allow testing for volumetric size changes between individual neural structures, including those most active during flight. This study also will use geometric morphometrics (anatomical comparisons) to assess covariation between neuroanatomical partitions and thus the presence of functionally and/or evolutionarily integrated regions of the brain. In short, the proposed study will generate data on how birds use their brain and apply those data to better understand the ancient relationship between brain evolution and the origin of the highly derived avian body plan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research under this collaborative grant was designed to expand the degree to which neuroscience, comparative morphology, and paleontology can be integrated to inform the deep evolutionary history of the vertebrate brain. We chose birds as the taxonomic focus of our work for several reasons. The distinctive nature of how birds increase brain size (encephalization) along with their unique behavioral repertoire, modern phylogenetic and ecological diversity, and famous evolutionary origin from among theropod dinosaurs provides a wealth of comparative opportunities. In addition, expanding our understanding of the patterns of how this encephalization facilitates comparisons with the parallel, and more intensely studied, expansion of the mammalian brain. The overarching goal of the collaborative grant was to: (1) use PET scanning to generate the first in-vivo functional data on what regions of the bird brain are differentially active during flight; (2) use newly derived staining techniques to generate digital neuroanatomical atlases for a variety of modern avian lineages to establish variation in the size and shape of functional regions within the brain across the bird tree, and to assess how that 3D variation is expressed superficially on the external brain surface; and (3) use the data generated under (1) and (2) to interpret the neuroanatomical significance of dinosaurian endocasts (reconstructions of the bony space housing the brain) and the deep history of the avian brain both within and outside the modern radiation of birds.

We successfully generated PET-based activity maps of the pigeon brain during rest and during flight. Acquiring and analyzing these data required the adjustment of protocols specifically designed for mammals. The innovations funded by this grant in the techniques of acquiring and registering avian PET data will facilitate future neuroscience research on other non-mammalian lineages. Differential analysis of our PET data indicates that flight incurs a marked increase in neuronal processing within those brain regions housing the primary motor pathways. In contrast, the major brain centers for processing sensory information tend to show reduced levels of activity during flight. A possible exception to this pattern is in those forebrain nuclei responsible for processing olfactory cues.  

Our research group produced three-dimensional, digital datasets of differentially stained brains for a significant number of living bird species. These data are being integrated with an increasingly broad sample of endocast data from both living bird species and from a variety of fossil theropod dinosaurs. This integration provides a deep perspective on the distinguishing features of the avian brain and the complex evolutionary influences that produced the high brain-to-body size ratio characteristic of modern birds. For example, it is now clear that the major pulses of avian encephalization actually occurred prior to the origin of avian flight. This conclusion reflects a more general pattern of discovery in which the features often conceptualized and discussed as uniquely avian find their actual origins among non-avian theropod dinosaurs. Based on data generated from this grant, that early evolutionary history is often associated with levels of variation and rates of evolution surpassing those found among modern birds.

One important discovery from our research that conveys the above points relates to a structure of the avian cerebrum called the Wulst, which processes both somatosensory and visual information. Long considered a feature unique to modern birds, our results indicate that the avian Wulst evolved under a multi-step model in which an internally complex and differentiated layer of the cerebrum called the dorsal pallium appeared prior to the crocodile-bird split and was thus present in all dinosaurs. Its expansion and organization into a Wulst proper occurred later, near the origin of maniraptoran dinosaurs, but still well before the appearance of crown birds. It is thus likely these dinosaurs were able to rapidly process and integrate sensory information with motor responses and enjoyed heightened cognitive function. At the same time, not all surveyed maniraptorans exhibit an obvious Wulst, suggesting the early history of this feature may have lacked the nuances of the form-function relationship apparent in living birds.

Thanks to the funding provided by this grant, we have expanded the analytical and conceptual toolkit available to comparative neuroscientists, and we are confident that this work will lead to even more important future research and discoveries. The specific data generated from our research studies establish a host of meaningful hypothesis that help explain both the functional influences that continue to shape the modern avian brain, but also the evolutionary complexities surrounding its deep-time origin from among cognitively underappreciated theropod dinosaurs.
